revisions.rev:
{{NBA season | team = Los Angeles Lakers | end_year = 2010 | wins = 57 | losses = 25 | division = Pacific | division_place = 1st | conf_place = 1st | coach = [[Phil Jackson]] | owners = [[Jerry Buss]] | arena = [[Staples Center]] | playoffs = [[2010 NBA Finals|NBA Champions]]
([[2010 NBA Playoffs#Bracket|won 4â3]]) | bbr_team = LAL | television = Home: [[Fox Sports West and Prime Ticket|FS West HD]] Away: [[KCAL-TV|KCAL 9 HD]] | radio = [[KSPN (AM)|710 ESPN]] }} The '''2009â10 Los Angeles Lakers season''' is the 64th season of the franchise, 62nd in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) and 50th in Los Angeles. Coming off a championship in 2009, the Lakers successfully defended their title. They spent the most money of any team on player salaries this season, totaling $112.7 million ($91.3 million on player salaries and $21.4 million on [[NBA Salary Cap#Luxury tax|luxury tax]]).http://www.nba.com/2009/news/features/scott_howard_cooper/11/26/and.one/index.html{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jun/18/sports/la-sp-lakers-whats-next-20100619 | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=After title time comes decision time for Lakers | first=Broderick | last=Turner | date=June 18, 2010}} The Lakers once again sold out all 41 home games for the season at [[Staples Center]]. The Lakers clinched the [[Pacific Division (NBA)|Pacific Division]] for the 31st time in franchise history. Despite winning eight games less than the previous season, they still held the top seed in the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] playoffs and made it to the NBA Finals for the third straight season. In the [[2010 NBA Finals]] the Lakers defeated the [[Boston Celtics]] in a rematch of the [[2008 NBA Finals]] won by the Celtics. This time, the Lakers won the series 4-3 for their 16th NBA title and handed Boston its first Game 7 loss in an NBA Finals in team history. [[Kobe Bryant]] won his second consecutive [[Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award|NBA Finals MVP]]. On July 14, 2009, [[Phil Jackson]] won the [[ESPY Awards 2010|2010 ESPY Awards]] for Best Coach/Manager while Kobe Bryant won for Best NBA Player. ==Key dates== *'''June 25''' â The [[2009 NBA Draft]] took place in [[New York City]]. *'''July 8''' â The [[free agent|free agency]] period started. *'''October 7''' â The Lakers played their first preseason game of the season against the [[Golden State Warriors]]. *'''October 27''' â The Lakers' [[2009â10 NBA season|regular season]] began with a home game versus the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. The previous year's players received their championship rings and the team raised their 15th championship banner into the [[Staples Center]] rafters. *'''January 25''' â The previous year's players and staff visited the [[White House]] to meet President [[Barack Obama]]. *'''February 12â14''' â The [[2010 NBA All-Star Game|2010 NBA All-Star Weekend]] took place. *'''March 19''' â The Lakers clinched a post-season berth for the 29th time in 31 years.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100319_MIN@LAL?tag=scores-1698868;links1698868 They are the first Western Conference team this season to clinch a playoff berth. *'''April 5''' â The Lakers clinched their third consecutive and 21st overall Pacific Division title Saturday night with the [[Phoenix Suns]]' loss at the [[Milwaukee Bucks]].http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100404_SA@LAL *'''April 9''' â The Lakers clinched the top seed in the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] with a win against the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]].[http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100409_LAL@MIN/kobeless-lakers-lock-up-no-1-seed-in-western-conference Kobe-less Lakers lock up No. 1 seed in Western Conference] [[CBSSports.com]] wire report, April 6, 2010 *'''April 14''' â The Lakers played their final game of the regular season in a road game against the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. *'''April 18''' â The Lakers played the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] in their first game of the [[2010 NBA Playoffs]]. *'''June 17''' - The Lakers beat the [[Boston Celtics|Celtics]] in Game 7 of the [[2010 NBA Finals]] to win their 16th NBA title.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/basketball/nba/gameflash/2010/06/17/28168_recap.html|title=Lakers edge Celtics in Game 7, win 16th title|date=2010-06-17|work=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=2010-06-17}} ==Offseason== ===Injuries=== The Lakers came into training camp with no serious injuries. All players were expected to be healthy enough to play in the season opener. After having surgery on his knee last season, [[Andrew Bynum]] was told that he has [[ligamentous laxity]], which required him to wear a knee [[brace (orthopaedic)|brace]] for the entire season.http://www.ocregister.com/articles/bynum-zarzana-knee-2595193-brace-lakers During training camp, [[D. J. Mbenga]] was not able to participate fully in practice due to a "malalignment of his hips/hip flexors". The imbalance was causing him pain in his abdominal, groin and hip flexor areas.http://my.lakers.com/blogs/2009/10/05/dj-mbenga-injury-update/ He made a full recovery and played on opening night. [[Pau Gasol]] injured his [[hamstring]] during a preseason game and missed the first 12 games of the season. In December, [[Ron Artest]] revealed that he suffered a shoulder injury during the Lakers' opening exhibition game. He kept the injury quiet so it wouldn't seem like he was making excuses, telling neither the media nor his coaches.http://www.pe.com/sports/breakout/stories/PE_Sports_Local_S_laker_notes_01.45ceacf.html ===Departures=== [[Trevor Ariza]] chose not to sign when the Los Angeles Lakers offered the Mid-Level Exception (approximately $6 million per year).http://www.cbssports.com/nba/story/11917471 When the Lakers looked towards other free agents, Ariza agreed to sign with the [[Houston Rockets]] for slightly more money. The Lakers had a [[NBA Salary Cap#Options|team option]] on [[Sun Yue (basketball)|Sun Yue]] to pick up his contract for one year paying him $736,000.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-lamar-odom23-2009jul23,0,5117681.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lamar Odom and Lakers resume talks | first1=Broderick | last1=Turner | first2=Mike | last2=Bresnahan | date=July 23, 2009}} But the Lakers decided to release him to keep the roster to 13 players.http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5j0H3Y8DgLSvvFP8OaqLzmTWsfC4wD99PQ4KO0 Sun eventually signed with the [[New York Knicks]]. Assistant coach [[Kurt Rambis]] left the Lakers to pursue a head-coaching position with the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]]. Rambis was believed to be the potential replacement to [[Phil Jackson]] if he leave in the next season.http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=4386466 ===Signings=== The Lakers had [[NBA Salary Cap#Options|team options]] to exercise contracts on [[Josh Powell]] and [[D. J. Mbenga]]. The Lakers decided to bring both Powell and Mbenga back, paying them $959,000 each.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers2-2009jul02,0,6815585.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lakers are far apart with free agents Trevor Ariza and Lamar Odom | first1=Mike | last1=Bresnahan | first2=Broderick | last2=Turner | date=July 2, 2009}} [[Kobe Bryant]] also had an option to terminate his contract this offseason, which would pay him approximately $23,000,000 for the season and $24,800,000 for the season after. He chose not to opt out of his contract and will sign a 3 year extension worth between 80 and 85 million dollars.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-kobe-bryant1-2009jul01,0,5024600.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=If Kobe Bryant wants a new contract, today's the deadline to ask | first1=Mike | last1=Bresnahan | first2=Broderick | last2=Turner | date=July 1, 2009}} [[Image:Artest Las Vegas.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Los Angeles Lakers (Artest and Mbenga pictured) at the [[Luxor Las Vegas]] after a pre-season game.]] [[Ron Artest]] was the first player from another team to sign with the Los Angeles Lakers this offseason. On July 2, Artest told [[CBSSports.com]] that he has agreed to a contract with the Lakers. He decided not to pursue a more lucrative contract from his former team (the Rockets) and signed a 5-year deal worth $33 million on July 8.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/story/11932269 The Lakers used their [[NBA Salary Cap#Mid-level exception|Mid-Level Exception]] to sign Artest. Artest has long wanted to play for the Lakers and was looking forward to playing with [[Kobe Bryant]] and childhood friend [[Lamar Odom]]. Artest changed his jersey number from 96 to 37 in honor of [[Michael Jackson]]'s album ''[[Thriller (album)|Thriller]]'' which was the #1 selling album for 37 weeks.http://www.ballerstatus.com/2009/07/09/ron-artest-becomes-a-los-angeles-laker-dedicates-jersey-song-to-michael-jackson/ Jackson died 13 days earlier. [[Shannon Brown]] agreed to a contract with the Lakers on July 6. Brown turned down a more expensive offer from the [[Indiana Pacers]] and agreed to a 2 year $4.2 million deal.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers7-2009jul07,0,2747762.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Shannon Brown returning to Lakers | first1=Mike | last1=Bresnahan | first2=Broderick | last2=Turner | date=July 7, 2009}} The Lakers used the [[NBA Salary Cap#Bi-annual exception|Bi-annual exception]] to sign Brown. He has a [[NBA Salary Cap#Options|player option]] to terminate his contract after the 2009-10 season.http://www.hoopsworld.com/Story.asp?story_id=13240 Lamar Odom was the last Lakers free agent to resign with the team. Before the previous season ended, Odom said he was willing to take a paycut from the $11.4 million he made in his final year of his contract (which was actually $14.1 million under the Lakers salary cap because the difference was paid upfront as a "trade-kicker" when he joined the Lakers). Early in July, the Lakers presented two offers to Odom:{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-odom31-2009jul31,0,5679779.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lamar Odom, Lakers agree to four-year deal | first=Broderick | last=Turner | date=July 31, 2009}} *A four-year deal for $9 million a season, worth up to $36 million, but only three years and $27 million was guaranteed, with the Lakers' buyout in the fourth year worth $3 million. *A three-year, $30-million deal that would have paid Odom $10 million a season. When Odom and his agent did not respond quickly enough, owner [[Jerry Buss]] pulled both deals off the table. At the same time, the [[Miami Heat]] actively pursue Odom. Heat President [[Pat Riley]] and [[Dwyane Wade]] met with Odom in Los Angeles in an attempt to get Odom to return to Miami. Afterwards, Odom spoke with Jerry Buss, and Odom's agent and Lakers General Manager Mitch Kupchak kept an open dialogue. On July 30, Lamar Odom agreed to a four-year deal, reportedly for $33 million, with a [[NBA_Salary_Cap#Options|team option]] for the final year. Odom said he did not want to leave [[Pau Gasol]], [[Andrew Bynum]], [[Derek Fisher]] and the rest of the Lakers, especially [[Kobe Bryant]]. On September 28, the Lakers signed four players to non-guaranteed contracts: [[Tony Gaffney]], [[David Monds]], [[MickaÃ«l Gelabale]] and [[Michael Fey]].http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/0909_training_camp_signees.html On September 30, the Lakers also signed [[Thomas Kelati]] to a non-guaranteed contract,{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/2009-09-30-3071576035_x.htm | work=USA Today | title=Lakers sign guard Thomas Kelati | date=September 30, 2009 | accessdate=April 23, 2010}} bring their total player roster to 18 players. By the beginning of the season, they had to reduce their roster to a maximum of 15 players. On October 10, the Lakers cut MickaÃ«l Gelabale, David Monds, and Michael Fey, bringing the roster to 15 players.http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/091010lakerswaivethree.html On October 21, Thomas Kelati was cut from the team.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-fyi22-2009oct22,0,2498370.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Andrew Bynum looks great, but games don't count yet | first=Mike | last=Bresnahan | date=October 22, 2009}} On October 24, the Lakers cut Gaffney.http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/091024_gaffneywaived.html ===Trades=== The Lakers traded their first round draft pick (#29) to the [[New York Knicks]] for $3,000,000 and the Knicks 2011 second round draft pick.http://www.ocregister.com/articles/lakers-draft-player-2475454-kupchak-pick The Lakers traded their second pick (originally from the [[Charlotte Bobcats]] for the [[Kareem Rush]] trade) for cash. ===Draft=== {{Main|2009 NBA Draft}} The Lakers originally had three picks entering the Draft. Their 29th pick was used to pick [[Toney Douglas]] from [[Florida State Seminoles men's basketball|Florida State]], and chose [[Patrick Beverley]] from [[Arkansas Razorbacks men's basketball|Arkansas]] with their 42nd pick, a pick which they got from a previous trade with Charlotte.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/rush_trade_041206.html|title=Lakers Trade Kareem Rush to Charlotte in Exchange for Two Future Picks|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|accessdate=2009-04-18|date=2004-12-06}} The Lakers traded both each for a future second-round draft pick and cash. They kept their final pick and selected [[Chinemelu Elonu]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/09draft.html|title=Lakers 2009 Draft Index|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|date=2009-06-26|accessdate=2009-07-09}} The [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]] center earned All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] honors last season after averaging 9.8 points and a team-best 7.3 rebounds and 53 blocked shots. He set a school record by making 66.5 percent from the field and was named the Big 12's most improved player.{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2009/06/29/Sports/Big-Draft.For.Big.12-3749370.shtml|title=Big Draft for Big 12: Griffin taken 1st overall, Elonu 59th|publisher=[[The Battalion]]|date=2009-06-29|accessdate=2009-07-09|author=Harris, David}} {| class="wikitable sortable sortable" ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="5%"| Round ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="5%"| Pick ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="15%"| Player ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="10%"| Position ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="20%"| Nationality ! style="background:#ffcd35; color:#6137ad" width="10%"| School/Club Team |- | 1 | 29 | [[Toney Douglas]] | Guard | {{USA}} | [[Florida State Seminoles men's basketball|Florida State]] |- | 2 | 42 | [[Patrick Beverley]] | Guard | {{USA}} | [[Arkansas Razorbacks men's basketball|Arkansas]] |- | 2 | 59 | [[Chinemelu Elonu]] | Power Forward | {{NGA}}/{{USA}} | [[Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M]] |- |} ==Roster== {{NBA roster header|team=Los Angeles Lakers }} {{player2 | num = 37 | nat = USA | first = Ron | last = Artest | pos = F/G | ft = 6 | in = 7 |lbs = 260 | college = St. John's University }} {{player2 | num = 12 | nat = USA | first = Shannon |last = Brown | pos = G | ft = 6 | in = 4 | lbs = 210 | college = Michigan State}} {{player2 | num = 24 | nat = USA | first = Kobe | last = Bryant | pos = G/F | ft = 6 | in = 6 | lbs = 205 | college = [[Lower Merion High School|Lower Merion HS (PA)]]| note = C }} {{player2 | num = 17 | nat = USA | first = Andrew | last = Bynum | pos = C | ft = 7 | in = 0 | lbs = 285 | school = [[St. Joseph High School (Metuchen, New Jersey)|St. Joseph HS (NJ)]] }} {{player2 | num = 1 | nat = USA | first = Jordan | last = Farmar | pos = G | ft = 6 | in = 2 | lbs = 180 | college = UCLA}} {{player2 | num = 2 | nat = USA | first = Derek | last = Fisher | pos = G | ft = 6 | in = 1 | lbs = 210 | college = University of Arkansas-Little Rock }} {{player2 | num = 16 | nat = ESP | first = Pau | last = Gasol | pos = F/C | ft = 7 | in = 0 | lbs = 250 | from = Spain }} {{player2 | num = 28 | nat = BEL | first = D. J. | last = Mbenga | pos = C | ft = 7 | in = 0 |lbs = 255 | from = DR Congo }} {{player2 | num = 6 | nat = USA | first = Adam | last = Morrison | pos = F | ft = 6 | in = 8 | lbs = 205 | college = Gonzaga | note = IN }} {{player2 | num = 7 | nat = USA | first = Lamar | last = Odom | pos = F | ft = 6 | in = 10 | lbs = 230 | college = Rhode Island }} {{player2 | num = 21 | nat = USA | first = Josh | last = Powell | pos = F/C | ft = 6 | in = 9 | lbs = 240 | college = North Carolina State}} {{player2 | num = 18 | nat = SLO | first = Sasha | last = VujaÄiÄ | pos = G | ft = 6 | in = 7 | lbs = 205 | from = Slovenia}} {{player2 | num = 4 | nat = USA | first = Luke | last = Walton | pos = F |ft = 6 | in = 8 | lbs = 235 | college = Arizona }} {{NBA roster footer |head_coach = * {{player||USA|[[Phil Jackson]]}} ({{college|North Dakota}}) |asst_coach = *{{player||USA|[[Frank Hamblen]]}} ({{college|Syracuse}}) *{{player||USA|[[Brian Shaw]]}} ({{college|UC-Santa Barbara}}) *{{player||USA|[[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]]}} ({{college|UCLA}}) *{{player||USA|[[Craig Hodges]]}} ({{college|Long Beach State}}) *{{player||USA|[[Jim Cleamons]]}} ({{college|Ohio State}}) |ath_train = *{{player||USA|Gary Vitti}} ({{college|Southern Connecticut State}}) |roster_url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/roster/ |transaction_url=http://www.hoopshype.com/general_managers/mitch_kupchak.htm |accessdate=2009-10-26 }} ===Depth chart=== {| style="text-align: center; background:#5C2F83; color:white" |- !width="40"|Pos. ! style="width:165px;"|Starter ! style="width:165px;"|Bench ! style="width:165px;"|Reserve ! style="width:165px;"|Inactive |- style="height:40px; background:white; color:white" ! style="background:#FCB926" | [[Center (basketball)|C]] | '''[[Andrew Bynum|Andrew Bynum]]''' || || [[D. J. Mbenga|D. J. Mbenga]] || style="background:#FCB926" | |- style="height:40px; background:white; color:white" ! style="background:#FCB926" | [[Power forward (basketball)|PF]] | '''[[Pau Gasol|Pau Gasol]]''' || [[Lamar Odom|Lamar Odom]] || [[Josh Powell|Josh Powell]] || style="background:#FCB926" | |- style="height:40px; background:white; color:white" ! style="background:#FCB926" | [[Small forward|SF]] | '''[[Ron Artest|Ron Artest]]''' || [[Luke Walton|Luke Walton]] || || style="background:#FCB926" | [[Adam Morrison|Adam Morrison]] |- style="height:40px; background:white; color:white" ! style="background:#FCB926" | [[Shooting guard|SG]] | '''[[Kobe Bryant|Kobe Bryant]]''' || [[Shannon Brown|Shannon Brown]] || [[Sasha VujaÄiÄ|Sasha VujaÄiÄ]] || style="background:#FCB926" | |- style="height:40px; background:white; color:white" ! style="background:#FCB926" | [[Point guard|PG]] | '''[[Derek Fisher|Derek Fisher]]''' || [[Jordan Farmar|Jordan Farmar]] || || style="background:#FCB926" | |} ==Season summary== [[File:Kobe speaks Lakers watch.jpg|thumb|250px|The Los Angeles Lakers on October 23, 2009 at the [[Bob Wilson Naval Hospital]] gym in [[San Diego]]]] The Los Angeles Lakers opened the season at home against their intra-city rival the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. Before the game, the remaining Lakers on the team from last year received their 2009 NBA championship rings. [[Pau Gasol]] missed the first 11 games due to his [[hamstring]] injury, so Lamar Odom moved to [[Power forward (basketball)|power forward]] and was placed in the starting lineup.{{cite web| url = http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20091027_LAC@LAL | title = Bryant, Lakers begin title defense with victory against Clippers | date = October 28, 2009 | publisher = [[CBSSports.com]] | accessdate = November 3, 2009}} The season opened with the starting lineup being: *PG â [[Derek Fisher]] *SG â [[Kobe Bryant]] *SF â [[Ron Artest]] *PF â [[Lamar Odom]] *C â [[Andrew Bynum]] The Lakers started off 7â1, then lost two in a row. [[Luke Walton]] was another player who was injured, suffering a pinched{{What|date=June 2011}} in his back on November 16.http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/news/story?id=4793739 He was out for approximately six weeks.{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/basketball/nba/lakers/2009-11-17-walton-pinched-nerve_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Lakers' Walton diagnosed with pinched nerve, to miss six weeks | date=November 17, 2009 | accessdate=April 23, 2010}} However, Gasol came back soon after and the Lakers returned to their normal lineup (with Odom coming off the bench): *PG â Derek Fisher *SG â Kobe Bryant *SF â Ron Artest *PF â Pau Gasol *C â Andrew Bynum [[File:BrownandBynum.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Brown and Bynum being guarded by [[Anthony Morrow]] and [[Chris Hunter (basketball)|Chris Hunter]]]] Through the first 14 games of the season, the Lakers ranked second in the league in defensive field-goal shooting (41.7%).http://www.hoopsworld.com/Story.asp?story_id=14474 They also had to deal with poor play by reserve players.http://www.dailynews.com/ci_13871499 After Gasol's return, the Lakers went 10â0, which included a game on December 4 when Bryant made a three-pointer as time expired to lift the Lakers past the [[Miami Heat]] 108â107.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20091204_MIA@LAL Their 11-game winning streak ended on December 12 against the [[Utah Jazz]]. On December 11, Bryant suffered a fracture in his right index finger in a game against the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]],http://sports.yahoo.com/nba/recap?gid=2009121113 but it didn't force him to miss any games. On December 16, Bryant made another game-winning shot, this time against the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] in overtime. The Lakers went on a five-game winning streak heading into their Christmas Day game at home against the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]]. They lost the game for their third home defeat of the season. Later that night, Ron Artest suffered a concussion from tripping over a box and falling down a flight of stairs.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-fyi1-2010jan01,0,1325605.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lakers forward Ron Artest trying to regain his touch | first=Broderick | last=Turner | date=January 1, 2010}} He missed five games to recover. The Lakers struggled with his absence, giving up 100 or more points in four consecutive games. On January 1, Bryant made a three-pointer at the buzzer to beat the [[Sacramento Kings]].http://sports.yahoo.com/nba/recap;_ylt=AlPw372uPqShjYE24OAV48G8vLYF?gid=2010010113 It was the third time that season that Bryant made a buzzer-beater to win a game. On January 3, Gasol mildly strained his left hamstring in the first quarter against the [[Dallas Mavericks]] and had to leave the game.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100103_DAL@LAL Artest returned to play the next game versus the [[Houston Rockets]], and Odom almost recorded a [[triple double]] with 17 points, 19 rebounds, and 9 assists.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100105_HOU@LAL After Christmas, the Lakers struggled, going 6â5. Since then, both Walton (28 games) and Gasol (six games) returned from injuries and the Lakers played with a full roster for the first time that season against the Clippers on January 15. [[File:LakersObama.bmp.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Barack Obama speaking with the Los Angeles Lakers on January 25, 2010, at the [[White House]]]] On January 21, the Lakers began the second half of the season by playing eight consecutive road games in 12 days. Beginning with a rematch of the Christmas Day game against the Cavaliers and concluding on February 1 against the [[Memphis Grizzlies]], the defending champions also visited the [[White House]] to meet President [[Barack Obama]]. {{listen |filename=Welcoming The Lakers To The White House (1-25-10) Barack Obama.ogv |title=January 25, 2010 White House Visit |description=On January 25, 2010, [[Barack Obama]] hosted the [[2008â09 Los Angeles Lakers season|2008â09 Los Angeles Lakers]] at the [[White House]] following their victory in the [[2009 NBA Finals]] to end the [[2008â09 NBA season]]. |filetype=[[Ogv]] |pos=left}} Against the Memphis Grizzlies, Bryant surpassed [[Jerry West]] to become the Lakers' all-time leading scorer. The Lakers finished the road trip 5â3. In February, Gasol was named winner of two of the three most prestigious annual awards given to European players, based on performances during the 2009 calendar year for both national and club teams. On December 27, Gasol was announced by the [[Italy|Italian]] magazine ''[[Superbasket Magazine|Superbasket]]'' as the winner of its ''[[Mr. Europa]]'' award{{cite news|url=http://www.reportonline.it/2009122739636/stampa-in-vetrina/superbasket-52-53.html |title=SuperBasket 52â53 |publisher=''Report On Line'' |language=Italian |date=2009-12-27 |accessdate=2010-02-05}} and on December 28, Gasol was announced by the Italian sports newspaper ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' as the winner of its ''[[Euroscar Award]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Sport_Vari/Basket/Estero/28-12-2009/europlayer-gazzetta-602467896186.shtml |title=Europlayer Gazzetta Pau Gasol fa il bis |publisher=''La Gazzetta dello Sport'' |language=Italian |date=2009-12-28 |accessdate=2010-02-05}} On February 6 against the [[Portland Trail Blazers]], an injured Bryant sat out for a game for the first time since 2007. Odom matched a career high with 22 rebounds in the Lakers' win, the first time they had won in Portland since 2005.http://www.nba.com/games/20100206/LALPOR/gameinfo.html Gasol produced 21 points, 19 rebounds, eight assists and five blocks in a win on February 8 against the [[San Antonio Spurs]], joining five other players to accomplish the feat.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-fyi10-2010feb10,0,6963981.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lamar Odom says he will play against the Jazz | first=Broderick | last=Turner | date=February 10, 2010}} The Lakers headed to the All-Star break on a three-game winning streak. All three victories came without Bryant and the final two were without Bynum. Bryant was voted as a starter for the [[2010 NBA All-Star Game]], but sat out due to injury. Gasol was selected as a reserve for the West and logged 13 points and six rebounds in 20 minutes.http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/boxscore?gameId=300214032 Brown entered the dunk contest but was defeated in the second round. [[File:2010 NBA Western Conference Playoffs qualifying.png|thumb|250px|Although the Lakers held the No. 1 spot in the Western Conference since December, they slowly saw that lead shrink over the rest of the season.]] Bryant returned from injury on February 23 against the [[Memphis Grizzlies]]. The Lakers went 4-1 without him. Bryant made a three-pointer with 4.3 seconds left to lift the Lakers to a 99-98 victory. However, the Lakers went 4-4 in the eight games after Bryant's return.http://nba.fanhouse.com/2010/03/07/gasol-has-inside-perspective-on-lakers-recent-woes/ Since the All-Star break, the Lakers have struggled, recording a 5-5 record including the first three-game losing streak since Gasol joined the team in a trade two years earlier. The team also had to deal with injuries to [[Sasha Vujacic]] and [[Luke Walton]].http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=5007392 The Lakers responded by winning five games in a row, but Bynum suffered an injury and was removed from the active roster.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-timberwolves-20100320,0,2710101.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lakers get ugly win over 'Wolves but lose Andrew Bynum | first=Mike | last=Bresnahan | date=March 19, 2010}} It was revealed that Bynum strained his [[Achilles tendon]] against the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]] on March 19, and that he was expected to miss almost two weeks (six games) to recover.{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-lakers-bynum-20100321,0,6219097,full.story | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Could have been worse | first=Broderick | last=Turner | date=March 21, 2010}} After their three-game losing streak, the Lakers responded by winning seven games in a row, then lost two of their next seven. They were the eighth best team in the Western Conference between the All-Star break and April 5 by record, but still held the top seed.http://www.nba.com/2010/news/powerrankings/04/05/week23/index.html?ls=iref:nbahpt1 Bryant chose to miss three of the final four regular-season games to recover from injuries.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100413_SAC@LAL Bynum returned from injury for the first game of the playoffs. ==Post-season summary== {{Main|2010 NBA Playoffs}} ===Oklahoma City Thunder=== [[Image:Andrew Bynum 2010 playoffs.jpg|thumb|250px|Andrew Bynum shoots a free throw against the Thunder in game 5.]] The Lakers played the [[Oklahoma City Thunder]] in the first round of the playoffs. Both Bryant and Bynum returned from injury to start in the first game. In game one, the Lakers outscored the Thunder 27-13 in the first quarter. The Thunder attempted to close in on the lead, but the Lakers held on in the 2nd half, matching the Thunder's point total in the 3rd and 4th quarter. Although Bryant led the Lakers in points scored (21), Gasol had the most impressive night statically, collecting 19 points, 13 rebounds, three assists, and three blocks. The series went to [[Oklahoma City]] for games three and four. The Thunder won both games including a 21 point win in game 4. [[Kevin Durant]] averaged 30.5 points in the two games to lead the Thunder. During the two games, the Thunder used their speed to run on the Lakers which translated into 24 fast-break points and 23 second-chance points in game 4.http://espn.go.com/nba/dailydime/_/page/dime-100424/daily-dime In game 5 in L.A., Gasol and Bynum combined for 46 points, 22 rebounds, and six assists in a 111-87 win.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100427_OKC@LAL/lakers-bounce-back-to-drill-thunder-in-game-5-take-32-lead Game six saw the Lakers returning to [[Oklahoma City]] were they could clinch the series with the win. The Lakers' bench outscored the Thunder's 30-16, however the Thunder claimed a one point lead with 3:04 to play.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100430_LAL@OKC With time winding down, Gasol caught an offensive rebound off of a missed jump shot by Bryant and scored a layup with 0.5 seconds remaining in the game for the win. ===Utah Jazz=== The Lakers next opponent was the [[Utah Jazz]] who advanced to the second round of the playoffs by defeating the [[Denver Nuggets]] 4-2. This was the third straight year the two teams met in the playoffs. The Lakers started off the first quarter shooting 79.8% from the field,http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/100502_gameday_jazz.html and leading by 10 at half time.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100502_UTA@LAL The Lakers gave up the lead in the 4th quarter before Bryant scored 11 points in the final four minutes to lead the Lakers to a 104-99 victory. Although Bryant had the most successful night in game 2, it was the Lakers front court of Gasol, Bynum, and Odom who dominated the game.[http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100504_UTA@LAL Lakers use size advantage to tune out Jazz, take 2-0 series lead] [[CBSSports.com]] wire reports Each had at least 11 points, 14 rebounds, and two blocks while the team outrebounded the Jazz 58-40 to a 111-103 victory. [[Andrei Kirilenko (basketball)|Andrei Kirilenko]] returned in game 3 from more than a month out with a strained left calf. While the Lakers' big men were dominate in the first two games, they had to rely on their backcourt in game 3 with Bynum and Odom being held in check.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100508_LAL@UTA Jazz coach [[Jerry Sloan]] said the Jazz's effort to keep the Lakers out of the middle opened up some 3-point shots and Los Angeles capitalized. Artest scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half while overcoming his three-point range slump in the playoffs. The fourth quarter had 12 lead changes, including Bryant and Fisher making back-to-back 3-pointers during an 8-2 run in the final minute. In the final four seconds, [[Deron Williams]] missed a shot and [[Wesley Matthews]] rebound and tip missed just before the end of the game. The Lakers won 111-110 and were on the verge of sweeping the Jazz. In game four, the Lakers jumped ahead and led by 22 points in the first half. The Jazz opened the third quarter with an 11-2 run and were able to cut the lead to 70-65, but the Lakers responded by finishing the period on a 10-2 run and led 80-67 at the end of the third quarter.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100510_LAL@UTA The Lakers led by 10 for most of the 4th quarter. Coach Phil Jackson called it "the first really consistent game we have played...We controlled the game and forced our will on our opponent." Bryant scored at least 30 points in all four games and the Lakers swept the series 4-0. ===Phoenix Suns=== The Lakers then faced the [[Phoenix Suns]] in the Western Conference Finals. In game 1, the Lakers blew out the Suns 128-107 led by Bryant's 40 points including 23 in the third quarter.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100517_PHO@LAL Odom came off the bench to tally 19 points, 19 rebounds, and three assists. In game 2 Bryant played the role of facilitator, putting up 13 assists, while Gasol recorded 29 points, 9 rebounds, and five assists.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100519_PHO@LAL The teams were tied at 90-90 heading into the fourth quarter, but Bryant and Gasol led the fourth quarter rally and the Lakers won the game 124-112. Game 3 was played in Phoenix, where the Suns used their big men and physical play to win the game.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100523_LAL@PHO [[Amar'e Stoudemire]] scored 42 points and grabbed 11 rebounds while [[Robin Lopez]] 20 points. Odom and Bynum, however, both picked up fouls early and were ineffective for the Lakers for most of the game. The Lakers only scored 15 points in the second quarter and were down 86-84 in after three quarters. The Lakers were able to take the lead 90-89 with 8:47 to play, but the Suns rallied back to win 118-109. After battling each other in game 4 and slugging out a 23-23 first quarter, the Suns erupted for a 41 points in the second quarter, shooting 74%.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100525_LAL@PHO Early in the 4th quarter the Lakers led 87-85. However, the Suns reserve players (who outscored the Lakers reserves 54-20) produced and 18-3 run in the 4th which the Lakers never recovered from despite Bryant's 38 points and 10 assists. In game 5, the Lakers surged to a 16 point lead in the first half including a 21-4 run and led by 18 points by half time. Steve Nash, who had 29 points and 11 assists in the game, led the Suns to a 16-4 rally in the third quarter to trim the lead to six by the end of the period and one with 2:52 left in the game.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100527_PHO@LAL [[Jason Richardson]] made a three pointer with 3.5 seconds left in the game to tie the score 101-101.On the next possession, Bryant, who had 30 points and 11 assists in the game, missed a shot, but Artest got the offensive rebound and made the game winning layup as time expired. In game 6 in Phoenix, the Lakers had the lead for most of the game. Los Angeles outscored the Suns 23-10 over the last eight minutes of the second quarter to lead 65-53 at the break and were up by 17 entering the fourth. However the Suns went on a 16-4 run and cut the Lakers lead to 95-90 with 6:09 remaining in the game.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100529_LAL@PHO Artest scored 25 in the game and Bryant had a 37 point performance including nine points in the final two minutes to win the game 111-103 and clinch the series 4-2. ===Boston Celtics=== {{Main|2010 NBA Finals}} ==Standings== 1.1 |} ==Awards and records== ===Awards=== *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named to the [[All-NBA Team|All-NBA First Team]] *[[Pau Gasol]] was named to the [[All-NBA Team|All-NBA Third Team]] *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named to the [[NBA All-Defensive Team|NBA All-Defensive First Team]] *The Los Angeles Lakers won the 2010 NBA Championship. *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named the 2010 [[Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award|NBA Finals MVP]]. ====All-Star==== *[[Kobe Bryant]] was voted to his 12th consecutive NBA All-Star Game as a starter. *[[Pau Gasol]] was selected to his third NBA All-Star Game. ====Weekly/Monthly==== *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named ''[[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Player of the Week'' for games played from November 16th through November 22nd.http://www.nba.com/cavaliers/news/potw_091123.html *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named ''[[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Player of the Week'' for games played from December 14 to December 20.http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=nba/news/newstest.aspx?id=4275059 *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named ''[[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Player of the Week'' for games played from December 21 to December 27.http://www.nba.com/2009/news/12/28/players.week/ *[[Kobe Bryant]] was named ''[[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Player of the Month'' for December.http://www.nba.com/2010/news/01/06/players.of.month/ *[[Pau Gasol]] was named ''[[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] Player of the Week'' for games played from March 15 to March 21.http://www.nba.com/2010/news/03/22/playersofweek ===Records=== *On November 6, [[Kobe Bryant]] moved past [[Allen Iverson]] into 16th place on the [[List of National Basketball Association career scoring leaders|NBA's career scoring list]].http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20091106_MEM@LAL *On November 6, [[Kobe Bryant]] became the youngest player (31 years, 75 days) in NBA history to score 24,000 points. *On November 19, [[Kobe Bryant]] passed [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]] (24,276) for second place on the Lakers' career scoring list.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20091119_CHI@LAL *On December 1, the Lakers tied the NBA record for most consecutive games (7) scoring at least 100 points and holding their opponent below 100, matching the mark set by the [[Milwaukee Bucks]] in January 2001.http://espn.go.com/nba/dailydime/_/page/dime-091204/daily-dime-live *On January 5, [[Kobe Bryant]] moved past [[Patrick Ewing]] into 15 place on the [[List of National Basketball Association career scoring leaders|NBA's career scoring list]].{{cite news| url=http://lakersblog.latimes.com/lakersblog/2010/01/kobe-bryant-moving-up-in-the-record-books.html | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lakers Blog | date=January 6, 2010}} *On January 13, the Lakers became the first franchise in NBA history to win 3,000 games.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100113_LAL@DAL *On January 21, [[Kobe Bryant]] became the youngest player in NBA history to score 25,000 points. *On February 1, [[Kobe Bryant]] moved past [[Jerry West]] into 14th place on the [[List of National Basketball Association career scoring leaders|NBA's career scoring list]]. He also surpassed West to become the Lakers franchise scoring leader.http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100201_LAL@MEM *On February 23, [[Kobe Bryant]] became the youngest player at 31 years and 184 days to play 1,000 games.http://espn.go.com/nba/dailydime/_/page/dime-100227-28/second-trimester-report *On February 24, [[Kobe Bryant]] moved passed [[Reggie Miller]] into 13th place on the [[List of National Basketball Association career scoring leaders|NBA's career scoring list]].{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/25/sports/la-sp-lakers-mavericks25-2010feb25 | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Lakers look tired in loss to Mavericks | first=Mike | last=Bresnahan | date=February 25, 2010}} *On March 25, [[Kobe Bryant]] moved passed [[Alex English]] into 12th place on the [[List of National Basketball Association career scoring leaders|NBA's career scoring list]].http://www.cbssports.com/nba/gamecenter/recap/NBA_20100324_LAL@SA *On May 2, [[Phil Jackson]] won his 103rd playoff game with the Lakers, passing Pat Riley for the franchise lead. *On May 29, [[Kobe Bryant]], with his 10th 30 point performance in his last 11 postseason games, moved ahead of Jerry West and into a tie with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar for second-most 30-point playoff games at 75. *On May 29, [[Kobe Bryant]] extended his NBA record to eight straight 30 point closeout games on the road. *On May 29, the Los Angeles Lakers extended their NBA record of most finals appearances to 31. *On June 7, the Lakers set an NBA Finals record by blocking 14 shots in a game.http://espn.go.com/nba/dailydime/_/page/dime-100608/daily-dime [[Andrew Bynum]] had seven blocks and [[Pau Gasol]] had six as they became the first teammates in Finals history to each have five or more blocks in a game. *[[Kobe Bryant]] became the first player to score 600 points in three consecutive playoff seasons.http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/0910seasonreview.html ==Transactions== {|
